title: 114_s2284
content: The text discusses the process by which a certification described in subsection (a) will not have any effect if a joint resolution disapproving the certification is enacted into law within 15 calendar days after Congress receives the certification. The joint resolution must be introduced within 3 calendar days, not have a preamble, and be titled "Joint resolution disapproving the certification of the President described in section 3(a) of the Syrian." The President's certification described in section 3(a) of the Syrian Refugee Verification and Safety Act can be disapproved by Congress through a fast-track process in the House of Representatives. Upon receipt of the certification, the Speaker of the House must convene the House within two calendar days for consideration of a joint resolution disapproving the certification. The House committee must report a joint resolution disapproving the President's certification within 5 days of receiving the certification. If the committee fails to do so, it will be discharged from further consideration of the resolution. The House committee must report a joint resolution disapproving the President's certification within 5 days. If the committee fails to do so or is discharged, the House can move to consider the joint resolution within 6 days. All points of order are waived, and the motion is not debatable. Upon receipt of a certification, the Senate can fast track consideration of a joint resolution. The majority leader can order the resolution to be passed without debate, except for two hours of debate controlled by the proponent and opponent. Reconsidering the vote on the resolution is not allowed. The Senate, upon receiving certification, must convene within two days. The joint resolution is immediately placed on the calendar and can be considered on the floor between the 4th and 6th day after certification. The Senate must convene within two days of receiving certification. The joint resolution can be considered on the floor between the 4th and 6th day after certification, with certain procedural rules in place. The joint resolution shall remain unfinished business until disposed of, with debate limited to 10 hours divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Amendments, motions to postpone, proceed to other business, or recommit the resolution are not allowed. The vote on passage is required. The joint resolution shall remain unfinished business until disposed of, with debate limited to 10 hours. The vote on passage shall occur immediately following the conclusion of the debate, with rulings of the chair on procedure decided without debate. Coordination with the other house is required before the passage of a joint resolution. If the House receives a joint resolution from the other House, it will not be referred to a committee. The House will vote on the joint resolution from the other House, following the same procedure as if no joint resolution had been received. The joint resolution from the other House will be the focus of the vote on passage. If one House fails to introduce or consider a joint resolution, the other House's joint resolution will receive expedited floor procedures. Following passage of a joint resolution in the Senate, the companion measure from the House will not be debatable. If the President vetoes the joint resolution, debate in the Senate will be limited to 1 hour. The rules of the House of Representatives and Senate regarding joint resolutions are enacted by Congress as part of each House's rules, applicable only to the procedure for joint resolutions and superseding other rules if inconsistent. Each House has the constitutional right to change its rules related to procedure at any time.
